reviewText: Will Smith's acting is superb in Legend.  He does a great job of portraying a very lonely man and how your mind would react to being the only 'normal' personal alive on earth.  However,I didn't care for parts in the story...too evil for me.In The Book of Eli, I loved Denzel but wished he could have taken off those sunglasses more often.  He also portrays a lonely man on a mission and certainly goes through the bad guys to get to his destination...a bit too much violence for me but love the way it leaves you wondering about him in the end.
summary: Two great acting jobs of lonely men

reviewText: Book of Eli: I recommend this movie to Denzel fans as his acting brings a new dimension to the post-apocalyptic genre. I think the movie itself is pretty good. Some like the religious tie-ins evident in the plot, some don't. You'll have to decide if you like your Sci-fi mixed with religious elements. If you do, than give this movie a look.I am Legend: This is quite a change from what author Richard Matheson had in mind for this post-apocalyptic tale in a number of ways. If you like to compare notes and go, why the heck did they do that? as you watch the movie, go get this one. The ending message has been changed which is worth noting as much of what the film version has included, specifically religious overtones, were not evident in the book. Again, it works well enough, but you have to ask yourself, especially if you are a fan of the book, if this change works for you. If you are new to this story, it is worth checking out for getting a glimpse of how someone, survives alone and still strives to get his job done, which is in this case, saving the world.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I recommend buying The Book of Eli, separately. Denzel does a great job.  I'd buy the Vincent Price version of I am Legend, which is, "The Last Man on Earth." Sadly, even with a multimillion dollar budget, Will Smith cannot outdo Vincent Price. Too bad they cast Smith in the movie. He is silly and unconvincing.As for the story, the message of I Am Legend/The Last Man on Earth ("LMOE") is prophetic, in much the same way that,  "The Time Machine" and "1984" showed us the terrifying future of declining, totalitarian western culture. When he wrote his book, Matheson could not have known of the coming, all-pervasive, mindlessness, "political correctness," and individual detachment brought on by immersion in technology, pseudo-science, media mind-control, and political group-think.  Nor could he have foreseen the all-encompassing totalitarian state. Nevertheless, Matheson describes modern society.The viral epidemic is an allegory for the spiritual, genetic and mental degradation of mankind. The dead come back to life. The dead are, of course, the soulless, mindless inhabitants of modern "progressive" society.  One need only observe expressionless, lifeless drones walking the streets and driving cars, totally immersed in telephones/computers, etc.,  to see that there is little life in these seemingly human forms (who have an uncanny resemblance to the Eloi in The Time Machine.Indeed, the "Vampires" are somewhat human in appearance, but noticeably crude, sickly and unintelligent. They are similar to the Morlocks in the Time Machine, and the know-it-all, Busybodies of modern totalitarian government. They seek to impose their will on others who are weak and vulnerable.There is an antidote to the virus of societal ignorance and degradation, but it is only temporary. If one remains immersed in the filth and degradation of modern society, if one still clings to the "virus" inside,  one can never be cured.There are some, however, such as Dr. Morgan, who are mentally, spiritually and physically, strong. These few are able to fight the ignorance and destruction brought on by the virus of totalitarian "progressivism."The most powerful clue to the meaning and lesson of the story is in the final scene. Morgan ends up on the Altar of a Church. There, the soulless barbarians sacrifice him to their own ignorance, creating  images of the execution of Jesus Christ. The savages could not bear to allow a free-thinking, healthy man to survive. To the totalitarian progressive, all must conform or perish. And Morgan committed, perhaps, the ultimate sin against totalitarian progressivism; he sought refuge in  God and the Church.Thus, the man who possessed the cure to the virus and the key to the salvation of mankind was killed by those who refused to accept and hated the Truth. Matheson accurately predicted the destructive modus operandi of the Vampires running the modern, totalitarian state, and the acquiescence of  healthy, but mindless citizens in their own destruction. Thus, the Last Man on Earth was killed in the same manner the modern government-media-political complex destroys the personhood and, when deemed necessary, the bodies of free men.
summary: Book of  Eli, Great; I Am Legend, Weak
